Explanation: Explanation: The y operator is used for yanking (copying) text. It is used in the same way as d operator is used i.e. it is also combined with itself or with another command. For example,5yy            // yanks five lines

Question: 5. For pasting text, ____ is used.
Explanation: Explanation: After yanking text with yy, we can paste it using either p or P. p paste the text below the current line while P paste the text above the current line.

Question: 6. c operator is used for changing the text.a) Trueb) FalseView Answer
Explanation: Explanation: For changing text, c operator is used. This operator is also combined with a command to perform the replacement. If dw deletes a word, cw changes it. This operator works in input mode. For example, to change the text from the present cursor location up to the end of line, usec$ or C

Question: 7. To change entire lines, ____ is used.
Explanation: Explanation: For changing text, c operator is used. This operator is also combined with a command to perform the replacement. To change entire lines, use the cc command.

Question: 8. Which operator is used in vi to filter text?
Explanation: Explanation: vi provides a marvellous feature of allowing UNIX filter to act on the text that’s displayed on the terminal. For filtering text screen,1. move to the beginning of the text to be acted upon and press !2. move to the other end of the text using navigation command like G3. Enter the command to act on the text.

Question: 9. To delete from current cursor upto the first occurrence of }, which of the following will be used?
Explanation: Explanation: We can perform many functions using operator-command combinations. For example, d / } will deletes from the current cursor upto first occurrence of } .

Question: 10. The command df. will _____
Option C: c) deletes from current cursor up to first occurrence of
Explanation: Explanation: The command df. is another example of operator-command combination. It deletes from cursor to first occurrence of a dot.

Question: 11. To yank from current cursor up to first occurrence of string str  in reverse direction, we can use:a) y?strb) y!strc) yy strb) yy ! strView Answer
Explanation: Explanation: The command y?str is another example of operator-command combination. The operator ? is used with y operator for yanking a string in reverse direction.

Question: 12. The following command will_________
Option C: c) changes the case of current line from lower to uppercase
Option D: d) changes the case of current line from upper to lowercase
Explanation: Explanation: The ! operator when doubled is used for operating on current line. For example, we can change the case of current line from lowercase to uppercase by using the above command.

Question: 13. The command c0 will change the text from current cursor to the end of line.a) Trueb) FalseView Answer
Explanation: Explanation: The command c0 will change the text from current cursor to the beginning of line.

Question: 14. To sort all lines from current cursor to end of line, ____ can be used.
Explanation: Explanation: The sort command is combined with ! and G operator for sorting from current cursor to the end of the line.

Question: 15. Which of the following is not a valid operator-command combination?
Explanation: Explanation: The command yy5 is not a valid one as we cannot prefix the command yy with an integer value.

Question: 1. Which of the following command is used for switching files?
Explanation: Explanation: We can switch between multiple files without quitting the vi editor. For example, while working with one file, we can switch to another by using the following command,	advertisement	    freestar.queue.push(function () { googletag.display('SanFoundry_300x250_320x50_320x100_inlist1'); });	:e  file02        // switches to file02

Question: 2. For returning back to the original file after switching we can use:
Explanation: Explanation: We can switch between multiple files without quitting the vi editor. For this purpose, :e command is used. For returning back to the original file, we can use one of the following commands:[Ctrl-^]            //toggles between previous and current file:e# 	           //same

Question: 3. When multiple filenames are used with vi, we can switch to next file using ___ command.
Explanation: Explanation: When vi editor is used with multiple filenames, it loads the first file. We can switch to next file using :n command.

Question: 4. We can move back to the previous file using ____ command.
Explanation: Explanation: When vi editor is used with multiple filenames, it loads the first file. We can switch to next file using :n command. In this manner, we can reach to the last file. At any stage, we can move back to the first file using :rew command.

Question: 5. :r  !date inserts the output of date command in our file.a) Trueb) FalseView Answer
Explanation: Explanation: We can also insert the output of any command in our file using :r command.

Question: 6. To split the screen into multiple windows, we can use ____ command.
Explanation: Explanation: We can also split our screen into multiple windows using :sp command. The window can be empty or it can contain a file, even a copy of the same file.

Question: 7. To create a new window, ____ can be used.
Explanation: Explanation: We can also create an empty window which will not be associated with any file. For this purpose, :new command is used. Now we can move between these windows using ctrl-w.

Question: 8. To remove all other windows except the current one, which of the following command is used?
Explanation: Explanation: To make the current window the only window on the screen and close all other windows use :on command. We can also kill the current window using :q.

Question: 9. vi editor has ____ named buffers.
Explanation: Explanation: vi editor stores the deleted text in an unnamed buffer. But this suffers some limitations. i.e. we can use only one buffer at one time. So vi uses 26 special named buffers which are named after the letters of the alphabet. For example,“a4yy            // yanks 4 lines into buffer a

Question: 10. To restore a number of recent deletions, numbered buffers are used.a) Trueb) FalseView Answer
Explanation: Explanation: We often need to restore a number of recent deletions. Vi editor makes it possible to restore up to recent nine complete line deletions using its numbered buffers. For example,“1p            // restores most recent deletion

Question: 11. For restoring the contents of numbered buffers efficiently, ___ command is used.
Explanation: Explanation: vi offers the dot command to restore the contents of any buffer efficiently. Every time this command is pressed, it steps through the buffer set to restore the contents of the next buffer.

Question: 12. The technique of restoring line deletions from numbered buffers is applicable only to entire lines.a) Trueb) FalseView Answer
Explanation: Explanation: The technique of restoring line deletions from numbered buffers is applicable only to entire lines. For example, we can’t restore five words deleted with 5dw unless it was the last editing action performed.

Question: 13. vi used ___ to enter control characters.
Explanation: Explanation: In vi, some characters are directly enterable, but a control character has to be preceded by another control character for it to be interpreted properly. Vi used ctrl-v to precede any control character.

Question: 14. To append contents of buffer to file01, we can use __________
Explanation: Explanation: The command :w >> file01 will append the contents of buffer to the file specified.

Question: 15. Which of the following is an invalid command?
Explanation: Explanation: : r file01 will read the contents of file01 below the current line. :e  file01 will stop editing the current file and will edit file01. Similarly, :e# returns to editing most recently edited file.

Question: 1. For searching a character, ___ and ___ are used.
Explanation: Explanation: For searching a character, we can take the cursor near or to a specific character in the current line. This is done with f and t commands.

Question: 2. For moving the cursor forward to the first occurrence of a character, __ is used.
Explanation: Explanation: For moving the cursor forward to the first occurrence of a character, f command is used followed by the character. For example,fch                // moves the cursor forward to the first occurrence of ch

Question: 3.  t command positions the cursor a single character before the occurrence.a) Trueb) FalseView Answer
Explanation: Explanation: t command works in a similar manner as f except the fact that it positions the cursor a single character before the occurrence.

Question: 4. __ and __ commands works in a reverse manner as f and t.
Explanation: Explanation: F and T perform the respective functions as f and t but in reverse direction.

Question: 5. For repeating the character search , and ; are used.a) Trueb) FalseView Answer
Explanation: Explanation: We can repeat the character search using the ; and , respectively. ; repeats the search in the same direction along which the previous search was made with f or t. Similarly (,) repeats the search in the opposite direction.

Question: 6. For customizing vi, which of the following command is used?
Explanation: Explanation: vi can be customized in the way we want. For this purpose, map, set and abbr commands are used.

Question: 7. vi environment is determined by variable settings. These variables are controlled by ____ command.
Explanation: Explanation: vi environment is determined by variable settings. These variables are controlled by :set command.

Question: 8. For automatic indentation, ____ is used with : set command.
Explanation: Explanation: To provide automatic indentation to or code, we can use the following statement::set  autoindent

Question: 9. Which of the following is used with :set to customize vi to ignore case in pattern searches?
Explanation: Explanation: To customize the vi to ignore case in pattern searches we can use the following statement:	advertisement	    freestar.queue.push(function () { googletag.display('Sanfoundry_300x250_320x50_BTF_1'); });	:set  ignorecase        // case-insensitive search

Question: 10. To change the default tab stop spaces in vi, ___ can be used with :set.
Explanation: Explanation: To change the default tab setting (8 spaces) to 4 spaces, :set tabstop=4 can be used.

Question: 11. Which command is used for mapping keys of keyboard?
Explanation: Explanation: The map command lets us assign the undefined keys or reassign the defined ones so that when such a key is pressed, it expands to a command sequence.

Question: 12. /* and f* are same.a) Trueb) FalseView Answer
Explanation: Explanation: /* will search the entire file for an asterisk, while f* looks for it in the current line only.

Question: 13. For compiling a C program without leaving the editor, which command will be used?
Explanation: Explanation: vi provides us with a feature of compiling a C program without leaving the editor by using the :!cc % command.

Question: 14. Which of the following statement is not true?
Option A: a) f and t commands are used for searching a character
Option B: b) y and yy are same
Option D: d) :e# is used for toggling between files
Explanation: Explanation: The y operator yanks text but it cannot perform any function unless it is combined with any command or itself.

Question: 1. A system call is a routine built into the kernel and performs a basic function.a) Trueb) FalseView Answer
Explanation: Explanation: All UNIX systems offer around 200 special functions known as system calls. A system call is a routine built into the kernel and performs a very basic function that requires communication with the CPU, memory and devices.

Question: 2. When we execute a C program, CPU runs in ____ mode.
Explanation: Explanation: When we execute a C program, the CPU runs in user mode. It remains it this particular mode until a system call is invoked.

Question: 3. In ____ mode, the kernel runs on behalf of the user.
Explanation: Explanation: Whenever a process invokes a system call, the CPU switches from user mode to kernel mode which is a more privileged mode. The kernel mode is also called as supervisor mode. In this mode, the kernel runs on behalf of the user and has access to any memory location and can execute any machine instruction.

Question: 4. All UNIX and LINUX systems have one thing in common which is ____
Explanation: Explanation: As we know that, all UNIX and LINUX systems have one thing in common; they use the same set of system calls.

Question: 5. The chmod command invokes the ____ system call.
Explanation: Explanation: Many commands and system calls share the same names. For example, the chmod command invokes the chmod system call.

Question: 6. For reading input, which of the following system call is used?
Explanation: Explanation: The standard C library offers a set of separate functions to read a block of data. For example, to read a block of data fread is used, for reading a line fgets is used and for reading a character fgetc is used. All these functions invoke the system call -read, which is available for reading input.

Question: 7. Which of the following system call is used for opening or creating a file?
Explanation: Explanation: To read or write to a file, we first need to open it. For this purpose, open system call is used. Open has two forms ; the first forms assumes that the file already exists and the second form creates the file if it doesn’t.

Question: 8. There are ___ modes of opening a file.
Explanation: Explanation: There are three modes of opening a file, out of which only one mode is required to be specified while opening the file. The three modes are, O_RDONLY, O_WRONLY, O_RDWR.

Question: 9. Which of the following mode is used for opening a file in both reading and writing?
Explanation: Explanation: There are three modes of opening a file namely: O_RDONLY    -    opens files for reading O_WRONLY    -    opens file for writing  O_RDWR      -   opens file for reading and writing

Question: 10. open system call returns the file descriptor as ___
Explanation: Explanation: open returns the file descriptor as an int. This is the lowest number available for allocation and is used as an argument by the other four calls (read, write, close, lseek).

Question: 1. Which of the following system call is used for closing a file?
Explanation: Explanation: A program automatically closes all open files before termination, but it’s a good practice to close them explicitly. The close system call is used for closing a file.int close (int fd)

Question: 2. close system call returns ____a) 0b) -1b) 1d) 0 and -1View Answer
Explanation: Explanation: The return type of close system call is an integer. It either returns 0 if the file is closed successfully or -1 otherwise.

Question: 3. ____ system call is used for writing to a file.
Explanation: Explanation: write system call is required for writing to a file which has previously been opened with the open system call. write system call returns the number of characters written.

Question: 4. write system call returns -1 when ___________
Option A: a) if disk fills up while write is in progress
Option C: c) if the file size exceeds the system’s limit
Option D: d) if disk fills up while write is in progress and if the file size exceeds
Explanation: Explanation: write system call returns the number of characters written. However, it will return -1 if if disk fills up while write is in progress or if the file size exceeds the system’s limit.

Question: 5. ____ system call is used for positioning the offset pointer.
Explanation: Explanation: The lseek system call moves the file offset pointer to a specified point. It doesn’t do any physical I/O rather it determines the position in the file where the next I/O operation will take place.

Question: 6. Which of the following offset is used with lseek system call to set the offset pointer to the end of the file?
Explanation: Explanation: The offset signifies the position of the offset pointer which can take one of these three values: SEEK_SET    -    offset pointer set to the beginning of file SEEK_END    -    offset pointer set to the end of file SEEK_CUR    -    offset pointer remains at current location

Question: 7.  Which of the following system call is used for truncating a file?
Explanation: Explanation: The truncate and ftruncate calls can truncate a file to any length. These calls are often used in combination with lseek to overwrite a certain segment of a file.

Question: 8. truncate needs the ___ of the file as an argument but ftruncate works with _______
Explanation: Explanation: The truncate and ftruncate calls can truncate a file to any length. truncate needs the pathname of the file as an argument but ftruncate works with the file descriptor.

Question: 1. Which library function is used for printing error messages?
Explanation: Explanation: The library function strerror, uses the error number as argument and returns a pointer to the string representing the error.

Question: 2. perror also uses error number to print the error messages.a) Trueb) FalseView Answer
Explanation: Explanation: There is another library function, perror which is used for printing the error messages. But perror doesn’t use the errno (error number) as an argument.

Question: 3. What is the significance of errno 13?
Option B: b) no such file and directory
Option D: d) no space left on device
Explanation: Explanation: The errno 13 displays the message “permission denied”. The symbolic constant for this errno is EACCES.

Question: 4. What is the symbolic constant for errno 2?
Explanation: Explanation: The symbolic constant for errno 2 is ENDENT. It displays the message “no such file and directory”.

Question: 5. Which of the following is not a valid symbolic constant?
Explanation: Explanation: EPERM displays not a super user (errno 1), ENDENT displays no such file or directory (errno 2), EEXIST displays file exist (errno 17).

Question: 6. How many data structures does the kernel maintain in memory that contain information about an open file?
Explanation: Explanation: The kernel maintains three data structures in memory that contain all information about an open file that a process needs to access. These data structures are:The file descriptor tableThe file tableThe vnode table

Question: 7. The file descriptor table contains all file descriptors for a process.a) Trueb) FalseView Answer
Explanation: Explanation: The file descriptor table contains all allocated file descriptors for a process. Each entry points to the file table. The file descriptor is stored along with a flag in this table.

Question: 8. The file table contains _________
Option D: d) mode of opening, status flags, offset printer and reference count
Explanation: Explanation: Every entry in the file descriptor table points to a file table. This table contains all the data which is relevant to an opened file.

Question: 9. The vnode table is also called _____
Explanation: Explanation: The file table contains a pointer to the vnode table, which is the third table in the scheme. It is also called as inode table. This table contains all the information present in the inode except that this structure is maintained in memory.

Question: 10. Which of the following system calls performs the action of cd command?
Explanation: Explanation: There are two system calls that perform the action of cd command. They are chdir and fchdir which uses pathname and a file descriptor respectively as an argument.

Question: 11. Directories can also be opened, read and written in the same way as regular files.a) Trueb) FalseView Answer
Explanation: Explanation: Directories are also files, and they can slo be written, read and opened in the same way as regular files. We can use open, close and read system calls for performing these tasks.

Question: 12. For creating and removing directories, which of the following system calls are used?
Explanation: Explanation: A non privileged user uses mkdir and rmdir calls for creating and removing directories respectively.

Question: 13. A super user can use ___ call for creating a directory.
Explanation: Explanation: A superuser can use the mknod system call to create a directory but a non privileged user has to use the mkdir call.

Question: 14. For creating a hard and symbolic link, which system calls are used?
Explanation: Explanation: Unlike the ln command which creates both hard and symbolic links, the sytem call library has two separate functions, link and symlink for these tasks.

Question: 15. For removing a link, ____ is used.
Explanation: Explanation: The unlink system call removes the directory entry for the file (the argument) and decrements the link count in its inode by one.

Question: 1. ____ system call is used for renaming a file, directory or symbolic link.
Explanation: Explanation: The rename call is used for renaming any type of file. It can rename a file, a directory or a symbolic link.

Question: 2.  S_IFxxx macros are used for checking the file types.a) Trueb) FalseView Answer
Explanation: Explanation: All UNIX systems provide a set of macros beginning with S_IF (often called S_IFxxx macros) that provide us with a function of checking the file type. But modern UNIX system performs this task in a more simplified manner using S_ISxxx macros.

Question: 3. Which of the following macro returns true if the file type is a directory?
Explanation: Explanation: The S_ISDIR macro returns true if the file type is a directory. The S_ISREG returns true if the file type is regular.

Question: 4. For checking a file access rights, ___ system call is used.
Explanation: Explanation: By using the access system call, we can check the file’s access rights. It looks at the real UID and real GID of the user running the program and determines that whether the file is accessible by the real user.

Question: 5. Which of the following is used with access call for checking the owner’s permissions?
Explanation: Explanation: By using the access system call, we can check the file’s access rights. We’ve to specify one of the following four values to define the permission which is needed to be tested.	advertisement	    freestar.queue.push(function () { googletag.display('SanFoundry_300x250_320x50_320x100_inlist2'); });	R_OK    -    read permission OKW_OK    -    write permission OKX_OK    -     execution permission OKF_OK    -    file exists

Question: 6. chmod and fchmod calls are used for changing file permissions.a) Trueb) FalseView Answer
Explanation: Explanation: chmod and fchmod calls are used for changing the file permissions. Chmod uses pathname for identifying a file while fchmod uses the file descriptor.

Question: 7. Both the owner and group owner can be changed by ____ call.
Explanation: Explanation: The chown system call is used to change both the owner and group owner. It has three states; chown, fchown, lchown.

Question: 8. For changing the time stamps, _____ system call is invoked.
Explanation: Explanation: utime system call is used to change a file’s modification and access times.

Question: 9. System calls and library functions are same.a) Trueb) FalseView Answer
Explanation: Explanation: System calls are built into the kernel, but library functions are built on top of them. When a system call is invoked, the pre-processor switches to kernel mode and returns to the user mode when the call completes.

Question: 10. Which of the following system call uses file descriptor as an argument?
Explanation: Explanation: A file descriptor is an integer which is allocated when a file is opened. It is used by all system calls that perform some operations on file -like read, write, close, lseek.

Question: 1. UNIX supports preemptive multitasking.a) Trueb) FalseView Answer
Explanation: Explanation: UNIX supports preemptive multitasking, which means that the kernel pre-empts the process when its time period expires.

Question: 2. The collection of memory locations that the process can access is called _______
Explanation: Explanation: Processes have their origin in executable program files on disk. The collection of memory locations that a process can access is called virtual address space. It is organized into a number of segments.

Question: 3. The virtual address space consists of ____ segments.
Explanation: Explanation: The virtual address space consists of a number of segments which are:•    Text segment•    Data segment•    Stack•    Heap•    Command line arguments and environment variables

Question: 4. The segment representing the constants, globals and static variables is called:
Explanation: Explanation: The segment representing the constants, globals and static variables which are used in the program is called data segment.

Question: 5. The stack stores the _______
Option D: d) arguments and local variables and address to return
Explanation: Explanation: The stack stores the arguments and the local variables of function as well as the address to return to. It grows and shrinks in size as functions are involved and complete execution.

Question: 6. The attributes of every process are stored in ____
Explanation: Explanation: The attributes of a process are stored in a fairly large data structure that represents an entry in the process table.

Question: 7. The entire process life cycle is built around ___ system calls.
Explanation: Explanation: The entire process life cycle is built around four system calls – fork, exec (not actually a system call), wait and _exit.

Question: 8. Which of the following system call is used for replicating a process?
Explanation: Explanation: The forking mechanism of process creation uses the fork system call to create a process. Each process is assigned a PID which is used for process handling purposes.

Question: 9. Which of the following functions is used for handling environment variables of a process?
Explanation: Explanation: Forking mechanism also transmits the parent’s environment to the child since environment variables are constituents of parent’s address space. POSIX specifies two functions getenv and setenv for handlings environment variables.

Question: 10. A process can be terminated using the exit or _exit system call.a) Trueb) FalseView Answer
Explanation: Explanation: If we place the exit or _exit system call anywhere in the program, the process will terminate as soon as that statement is executed.

Question: 11. Both exit and _exit system call share an identical syntax.a) Trueb) FalseView Answer
Explanation: Explanation: exit and _exit are one of the four basic system calls used in the process life cycle. They both share an identical syntax.void _exit (int status;)void exit (int status);

Question: 12. The parent process picks up the exit status of a child using ___ system call.
Explanation: Explanation: When a child process terminates, its exit status is placed along with other information in the process table. The parent picks this exit status using the wait system call.

Question: 13. Which of the following system call is more powerful (in waiting mechanism) than wait system call?
Explanation: Explanation: wait system call suffers from a number of limitations. It blocks until a child dies and if a parent spawns several children, wait returns the moment one of them dies. Wait also can’t handle process group. For these reasons, the waitpid system call is used.

Question: 14. If the child dies first but the entry of that child in the process table is still present, then that process is called ____
Explanation: Explanation: If the child dies first but the entry of that child in the process table is still presnt, then that process is said to be zombie state.

Question: 15. Every process belongs to a process group.a) Trueb) FalseView Answer
Explanation: Explanation: Every process belongs to a process group. Each process in the group has the same process group-id. The group has a leader whose process group ID is same as its PID.

Question: 1. ____ exec is responsible for executing programs on a UNIX system.a) Trueb) FalseView Answer
Explanation: Explanation: If we want to run a separate program in a forked process, it is done by exec. This operation replaces the entire address space with that of a new program. In other words, the fork is responsible for creating a process but it actually the exec that executes the program on a UNIX system.

Question: 2. Which of the following system call is used for duplicating file descriptor?
Explanation: Explanation: The dup system call supplicates the file descriptor fields and returns the lowest number available for allocation.

Question: 3. We can also duplicate the file descriptor using ___
Explanation: Explanation: Sometimes, dup call can fail in duplicating a file descriptor. In that case, the dup2 system call is used which provides a better way of replicating file descriptor.

Question: 4. Which of the following system call is preferred over dup and dup2 for replicating file descriptor?
Explanation: Explanation: POSIX calls dup and dup2 “redundant” functions and advocates the use of fcntl system call.

Question: 5. Which of the following system call is used for inter-process communication?
Explanation: Explanation: UNIX has a very elaborative scheme for two processes to communicate with each other. Pipe is a system call which provides a half-duplex communication channel. Pipe takes an array of two integers as its only argument, which it populates with two file descriptors.

Question: 6. We can use pipe with fork system call.a) Trueb) FalseView Answer
Explanation: Explanation: To make pipe work in tandem with fork, the usual procedure is to create the pipe before forking the process.

Question: 7. The action that a signal takes on receipt of a signal is called ____
Explanation: Explanation: A signal is represented by an integer and its symbolic name. A signal is a mechanism used by the kernel to communicate the occurrence of an event to a process. The action that a signal takes on receipt of a signal is called disposition.

Question: 8. The sources from where the signals can be generated are:
Option D: d) keyboard, hardware, a C program
Explanation: Explanation: The event that generates the signal can take place in the hardware, in the OS or elsewhere. It can be generated from the keyboard eg; SIGINT signal or it can be generated from the hardware eg; SIGILL.

Question: 9. There are _____ signals that are generated from the keyboard.
Explanation: Explanation: There are 3 signals that have their origin in the keyboard and all these three signals affect the foreground job. For example, ctrl-c generates the SIGINT signal (terminates the process), ctrl-\ generates the SIGQUIT signal which directs a process to produce a core dump, ctrl-z sends SIGSTOP to all the processes of foreground process group.

Question: 10. Which of the following signals are generated from the hardware?
Explanation: Explanation: Signals can be generated from hardware too like SIGFPE is generated on accoubt of an arithmetic operation, SIGILL is generated for illegal instruction and SIGSEGV is generated for memory access violation. All these signals result in termination of the process.

Question: 1. ___ system call behaves in an identical manner to the kill command.
Explanation: Explanation: kill system call behaves in an identical manner to the kill command. kill sends a signal but doesn’t necessarily kill a process.

Question: 2. Which library function uses kill to send any signal to the current process?
Explanation: Explanation: kill sends a signal but doesn’t necessarily kill a process. Kill system call is used by the library function raise to send any signal to the current process.

Question: 3. Which system call is used to set a timer that generates the SIGALARM signal?
Explanation: Explanation: The alarm call is used to set a timer that generates the SIGALRM signal after the timeout period.

Question: 4. If two users execute the same program, the memory requirements are doubled.a) Trueb) FalseView Answer
Explanation: Explanation: If two users execute the same program then memory requirements are not doubled, the text segment in the virtual address space is shared.

Question: 5. Address space of a process is virtual.a) Trueb) FalseView Answer
Explanation: Explanation: We say that address space of a process is virtual because the address specified in the executable doesn’t point to the actual memory location. The virtual addresses are translated into physical address at runtime by memory management unit (MMU).

Question: 6. Which of the following system calls returns one or more file descriptors?
Option D: d) dup, dup2, fcntl and pipe
Explanation: Explanation: dup, dup2, fcntl and pipe are the system calls which returns one or more file descriptors when invoked.

Question: 7. The environment variables are available in _____
Explanation: Explanation: The environment variables transmitted from parent process to child are available in environ[ ] variable.

Question: 8. Which of the following functions are used for obtaining and setting the value of environment variables?
Explanation: Explanation: The environment variables transmitted from parent process to child are available in environ[ ] variable. POSIX specifies two functions, getenv and setenv to obtain and set these values.

Question: 9. Which of the following action can be taken by a process upon receiving a signal?
Option D: d) ignore the signal, terminate and suspend the process
Explanation: Explanation: How a process responds to a signal depends on how things are set up in the program representing the process. However, there are mainly three actions that a program can take upon receiving a signal i.e. ignore the signal and continue execution normally, terminate the process, suspend (stop) the program.

Question: 10. What is the default disposition of most signals?
Explanation: Explanation: The action that a signal takes on receipt of a signal is called disposition. The default disposition of most signals is to terminate the process.

Question: 1. Which of the following resources are required to be managed and monitored?
Option D: d) CPU time, I/O time, disk space
Explanation: Explanation: A typical UNIX system has some major resources that are required to be monitored. These resources include CPU time, I/O time, disk space, network time. There are many tools available which provides us guidelines on how to diagnose and fix performance problems.

Question: 2. System time comprises ____ components.
Explanation: Explanation: There are five major components which take up the system time. These are -User state CPU, system state CPU, I/O time and network time, virtual memory performance, application program.

Question: 3. Which command is used to display all the running and active real-time processes?
Explanation: Explanation: top command is system monitoring program which is used to display all the running and active real-time process. It displays CPU usage, memory usage, swap memory, cache size, buffer size, process PID and much more.

Question: 4. ____ command displays the list of all open files and processes.
Explanation: Explanation: lsof command is a system monitoring program which displays the list of all open files and processes. The open file includes pipe, devices, network sockets, disk files, processes.

Question: 5. ____ is a simple tool that will collect and show system input and output storage device statistics.
Explanation: Explanation: Iostat is a system monitoring tool which is used to display system input and output storage device statistics.

Question: 6. sar is a command line tool for collecting, viewing and recording performance data.a) Trueb) FalseView Answer
Explanation: Explanation: sar is a command line tool for collecting, viewing and recording performance data. Sar (system activity report) is used to report on various system loads, including system loads, CPU activity, memory/paging, device load, network.

Question: 7. To override the default action and catch the signal ____ system call is used.
Explanation: Explanation: The default disposition of a signal is to terminate the process. However, we can override the default action and catch the signal using system call using the signal system call. Using signal system call.

Question: 8. Which of the following functions can be performed using signal system call?
Option C: c) invoke a signal handling function
Option D: d) ignore the signal, restore the default and invoke a signal handling function

Question: 9. Which of the following signals can neither be ignored nor catch?
Explanation: Explanation: Irrespective of the action you take, there are two signals that we can neither ignore nor catch by invoking a signal handler. They are SIGKILL and SIGSTOP.
